statement.text: Photoplethysmography (PPG) uses infrared light to detect blood volume changes in the cutaneous microcirculation, providing waveform analysis and enabling toe pressure measurement when standard ABI is unreliable due to calcification.

explanation.intuition: PPG shines a light into your skin and measures how much bounces back. When blood pulses through, the amount of light absorbed changes. This creates a wave pattern that tells us about blood flow to the digits.
explanation.key_insight: PPG-derived toe pressures are invaluable when ankle pressures are falsely elevated due to medial arterial calcification (common in diabetics). Toe pressure >30mmHg suggests adequate perfusion for healing.
explanation.technical_details: Mechanism: LED emits infrared light (940nm), photodetector measures reflected light which varies with blood volume. Applications: (1) Waveform analysis - normal vs blunted vs flat, (2) Toe systolic pressure with cuff occlusion, (3) Venous reflux evaluation. Toe pressure: place cuff on proximal phalanx, inflate until PPG signal lost, deflate until signal returns. Normal toe pressure >70% of brachial. Healing threshold: >30mmHg.

clinical_features.mechanism: Infrared light absorption varies with cutaneous blood volume
clinical_features.toe_pressure_technique: Cuff on proximal phalanx, inflate until signal lost, deflate to return
clinical_features.advantage: Reliable when ABI falsely elevated (calcified vessels)

clinical_pearls: Use toe pressure when ABI unreliable (diabetics, calcified vessels)
Toe pressure >30mmHg suggests adequate perfusion for healing
Flat PPG waveform indicates severe digital ischemia
